<h3><a id="user-content-stringifor-strings-fortran-manipulator-yet-another-strings-fortran-module" class="anchor" href="#stringifor-strings-fortran-manipulator-yet-another-strings-fortran-module" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>StringiFor, Strings Fortran Manipulator, yet another strings Fortran module</h3>

<p>A KISS pure Fortran library providing  astrings (class) manipulator for modern (2003+) Fortran projects.</p>

<ul>
<li>StringiFor is a pure Fortran (KISS) library providing a strings manipulator for modern Fortran projects;</li>
<li>StringiFor is Fortran 2003+ standard compliant;</li>
<li>StringiFor is OOP designed;</li>
<li>StringiFor is TDD designed;</li>
<li>StringiFor is a Free, Open Source Project.</li>
</ul>

<h5><a id="user-content-gnu-partial-support" class="anchor" href="#gnu-partial-support" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>GNU partial support</h5>

<blockquote>
<p>GNU gfortran does not support user-defined-type-IO, thus some class features are disabled if GNU is used.</p>
</blockquote>

<hr>

<p><a href="#what-is-stringifor?">What is StringiFor?</a> | <a href="#main-features">Main features</a> | <a href="#copyrights">Copyrights</a> | <a href="#download">Download</a> | <a href="#compilation">Compilation</a> | <a href="#documentation">Documentation</a> | <a href="#comparison-to-other-approaches">Comparison to other Approaches</a></p>

<hr>

<h2><a id="user-content-what-is-stringifor" class="anchor" href="#what-is-stringifor" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>What is StringiFor?</h2>

<p>Modern Fortran standards (2003+) have introduced a better support for characters variables, but Fortraners still do not have the power on dealing with strings of other more-rich-programmers, e.g. Pythoners. Allocatable deferred length character variables are now quantum-leap with respect the old inflexible Fortran characters, but it is still not enough for many Fortraners. Moreover, Fortran does not provide builtin methods for widely used strings manipulations offered by other languages, e.g. UPPER/lowercase transformation, tokenization, etc... StringiFor attempts to fill this lack.</p>

<p>Go to <a href="#top">Top</a></p>

<h2><a id="user-content-main-features" class="anchor" href="#main-features" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Main features</h2>

<p>StringiFor exposes only one class (OO-designed), the <code>string</code> type, that should be used as a more powerful string variable with respect a standard Fortran <code>character</code> variable. The main features of this class are:</p>

<ul class="contains-task-list">
<li class="task-list-item"><input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" checked="" disabled=""> seamless interchangeability with standard character variables, e.g. concatenation, IO, etc...;</li>
<li class="task-list-item"><input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" checked="" disabled=""> handy builtin methods, e.g. split, search, basename, join, etc...;</li>
<li class="task-list-item"><input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" checked="" disabled=""> low memory consumption: only one deferred length allocatable character member is stored, allowing for efficient memory allocation in array of strings, the elements of which can have different lengths;</li>
<li class="task-list-item"><input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" checked="" disabled=""> safe: almost all methods are elemental or pure;</li>
<li class="task-list-item"><input type="checkbox" class="task-list-item-checkbox" checked="" disabled=""> robust: the library is Test Driven Developed <a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Test-driven_development">TDD</a>, a comprehensive tests suite is provided.</li>
</ul>

<p>Any feature request is welcome.</p>

<p>Go to <a href="#top">Top</a></p>

<h2><a id="user-content-copyrights" class="anchor" href="#copyrights" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Copyrights</h2>

<p>Anyone is interest to use, to develop or to contribute to StringiFor is welcome, feel free to select the license that best matches your soul!</p>

<p>More details can be found on <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/wiki/Copyrights">wiki</a>.</p>

<h2><a id="user-content-download" class="anchor" href="#download" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Download</h2>

<p>StringiFor home is at <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor">https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor</a>. It uses <code>git submodule</code> to handle the third party dependency. To download all the source files you can:</p>

<ul>
<li>clone recursively this repository: <code>git clone --recursive https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor</code></li>
<li>download the latest master-branch archive at <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/archive/master.zip">https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/archive/master.zip</a></li>
<li>download a release archive at <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/releases">https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/releases</a></li>
</ul>

<p>Go to <a href="#top">Top</a></p>

<h2><a id="user-content-compilation" class="anchor" href="#compilation" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Compilation</h2>

<p>StringiFor is a modern Fortran project thus a modern Fortran compiler is need to compile the project. In the following table the support for some widely-used Fortran compilers is summarized.</p>

<p>The library is modular, namely it exploits Fortran modules. As a consequence, there is compilation-cascade hierarchy to build the library. To correctly build the library the following approaches are supported</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="#build-by-means-of-fobis">Build by means of FoBiS</a>: full support;</li>
<li><a href="#build-by-means-of-fobis">Build by means of GNU Make</a>: support only Intel Fortran;</li>
<li><a href="#build-by-means-of-fobis">Build by means of CMake</a>: to be implemented.</li>
</ul>

<p>The FoBiS building support is the most complete, as it is the one used for the developing StringiFor.</p>

<h3><a id="user-content-build-by-means-of-fobis" class="anchor" href="#build-by-means-of-fobis" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build by means of FoBiS</h3>

<p>A <code>fobos</code> file is provided to build the library by means of the Fortran Building System <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/FoBiS">FoBiS</a>.</p>

<h4><a id="user-content-build-all-tests" class="anchor" href="#build-all-tests" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build all tests</h4>

<p>Type</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre>FoBiS.py build</pre></div>

<p>After (a successuful) building a directory <code>./exe</code> is created containing all the compiled tests that constitute the StringiFor <em>regression-tests-suite</em>, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre>→ FoBiS.py build
Builder options

<h4><a id="user-content-build-the-library" class="anchor" href="#build-the-library" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build the library</h4>

<p>Type</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre><span class="pl-c"># static-linked library by means of GNU gfortran</span>
FoBiS.py build -mode stringifor-static-gnu

<span class="pl-c"># shared-linked library by means of GNU gfortran</span>
FoBiS.py build -mode stringifor-shared-gnu

<span class="pl-c"># static-linked library by means of Intel Fortran</span>
FoBiS.py build -mode stringifor-static-intel

<span class="pl-c"># shared-linked library by means of Intel Fortran</span>
FoBiS.py build -mode stringifor-shared-intel</pre></div>

<p>The library will be built into the directory <code>./lib</code>.</p>

<h3><a id="user-content-list-other-fobos-modes" class="anchor" href="#list-other-fobos-modes" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>List other fobos modes</h3>

<p>To list all <em>fobos-provided</em> modes type</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre>→ FoBiS.py build -lmodes
The fobos file defines the following modes:
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>tests-gnu<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>tests-gnu-debug<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>tests-intel<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>tests-intel-debug<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>stringifor-static-gnu<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>stringifor-shared-gnu<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>stringifor-static-intel<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>
  - <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>stringifor-shared-intel<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span></pre></div>

<p>It is worth to note that the first mode is the one automatically called by <code>FoBiS.py build</code>.</p>

<h3><a id="user-content-build-by-means-of-gnu-make" class="anchor" href="#build-by-means-of-gnu-make" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build by means of GNU Make</h3>

<p>The provided makefile support only Intel Fortran Compiler and it has two main building rules:</p>

<ul>
<li>build the (static linked) library;</li>
<li>build the tests suite.</li>
</ul>

<p>To build the library type</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre>make</pre></div>

<p>The library will be built into the directory <code>./lib</code>.</p>

<p>To build the tests suite type</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell"><pre>make TESTS=yes</pre></div>

<p>The tests will be built into the directory <code>./exe</code>.</p>

<h3><a id="user-content-build-by-means-of-cmake" class="anchor" href="#build-by-means-of-cmake" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Build by means of CMake</h3>

<p>To be done.</p>

<p>Go to <a href="#top">Top</a></p>

<h2><a id="user-content-documentation" class="anchor" href="#documentation" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Documentation</h2>

<p>The StringiFor documentation is mainly contained into this file (it has its own <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/wiki">wiki</a> with some less important documents). Detailed documentation of the API is contained into the <a href="http://szaghi.github.io/StringiFor/index.html">GitHub Pages</a> that can also be created locally by means of <a href="https://github.com/cmacmackin/ford">ford tool</a>.</p>

<ul>
<li><a href="#a_taste_of_stringifor">A Taste of StringiFor</a>

<ul>
<li><a href="#basic_io">Basic IO</a></li>
<li><a href="#string_manipulation">String manipulation</a></li>
<li><a href="#numbers_handling">Numbers handling</a></li>
<li><a href="#complex_scenario">Complex scenario</a></li>
</ul></li>
<li><a href="#methods-api">Methods API</a></li>
</ul>

<hr>

<h3><a id="user-content-a-taste-of-stringifor" class="anchor" href="#a-taste-of-stringifor" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>A Taste of StringiFor</h3>

<p>StringiFor is very handy...</p>

<h4><a id="user-content-basic-io" class="anchor" href="#basic-io" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Basic IO</h4>

<p>The class <code>string</code>  IO is overloaded by defined write/read TBP. Moreover, dedicated methods and operators can be exploited for IO, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">use</span> stringifor
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Hello World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>chars() <span class="pl-c">! "chars" method returns a standard character variable</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(DT)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring        <span class="pl-c">! defined IO is not enabled with GNU gfortran</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>     <span class="pl-c">! on-the-fly conversion to standard character by means of concatenation</span></pre></div>

<h4><a id="user-content-string-manipulation" class="anchor" href="#string-manipulation" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>String manipulation</h4>

<p>The class <code>string</code> has many methods for a plethora of strings manipulations, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">use</span> stringifor
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> strings(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>)

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>0123456789<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>reverse()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "9876543210"</span>

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Hello World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span><span class="pl-k">replace</span>(old<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, new<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>People<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "Hello People"</span>

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Hello World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
strings <span class="pl-k">=</span> astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>partition(sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>lo Wo<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Before sep: "<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>strings(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>"<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "Hel"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Sep itself: "<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>strings(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>"<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "lo Wo"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>After sep:  "<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>strings(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>"<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "rld"</span>

strings(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>one<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
strings(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>two<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
strings(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>three<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(strings)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>          <span class="pl-c">! print "onetwothree"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(strings, sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>-<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "one-two-three"</span>

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span> a StraNgE caSe var<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>camelcase()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print " AStrangeCaseVar"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>snakecase()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print " a_strange_case_var"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>startcase()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print " A Strange Case Var"</span></pre></div>

<h4><a id="user-content-numbers-handling" class="anchor" href="#numbers-handling" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Numbers handling</h4>

<p>StringiFor, by means of the <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/PENF">portability environment library, PENF</a> can handle numbers (reals and integers) effortless. The string/number <em>casting</em> (to/from and viceversa) is done by overloaded assignments (for all kinds of integers and reals). For convenience, StringiFor exposes the PENF number <em>portable</em> kind parameters.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">use</span> stringifor
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">127</span> _I1P       <span class="pl-c">! "I1P" is the PENF kind for 1-byte-like integer.</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "+127"</span>

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">3.021e6_R4P</span>    <span class="pl-c">! "R4P" is the PENF kind for 4-byte-like real.</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "+0.302100E+07"</span>

astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>3.4e9<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! assign to a string without the necessity to define a real kind</span>
<span class="pl-k">if</span> (astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>is_number()) <span class="pl-k">then</span>
  <span class="pl-k">if</span> (astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>is_real()) <span class="pl-k">then</span>
    <span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(E13.6)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>to_number(kind<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1._R4P</span>) <span class="pl-c">! print " 0.340000E+10" using a 4-byte-like kind</span>
  <span class="pl-k">endif</span>
<span class="pl-k">endif</span></pre></div>

<h4><a id="user-content-complex-scenario" class="anchor" href="#complex-scenario" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Complex scenario</h4>

<p>StingiFor is developed to improve the poor Fortran people with <em>daily</em> strings-usage, however, also complex scenario is taken into account, e.g. file parsing, OS operations, etc...</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">use</span> stringifor
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring

<span class="pl-c">! OS like manipulation</span>
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>/bar/foo.tar.bz2<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>basedir()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>                       <span class="pl-c">! print "/bar"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>basename()<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>                      <span class="pl-c">! print "foo.tar.bz2"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>basename(extension<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>.tar<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>      <span class="pl-c">! print "foo"</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>basename(last_extension<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">.true.</span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "foo.tar"</span>

<span class="pl-c">! XML like tag parsing</span>
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>&lt;test&gt; &lt;first&gt; hello &lt;/first&gt; &lt;first&gt; not the first &lt;/first&gt; &lt;/test&gt;<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>search(tag_start<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>&lt;first&gt;<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, tag_end<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>&lt;/first&gt;<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! print "&lt;first&gt; hello &lt;/first&gt;"</span></pre></div>

<h5><a id="user-content-a-naive-csv-parser" class="anchor" href="#a-naive-csv-parser" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>A naive CSV parser</h5>

<p>This is just a provocation, but with StringiFor it is easy to develop a naive CSV parser. Let us assume we want to parse a cars-price database as the following one</p>

<pre lang="csv"><code>Year, Make, Model, Description, Price
1997, Ford, E350   , ac abs moon, 3000.00
1999, Chevy, Venture "Extended Edition"  , , 4900.00
1999, Chevy, Venture "Extended Edition Very Large", , 5000.00
</code></pre>

<p>Well, parsing it and handling its cells values is very easy by means of StringiFor</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">use</span> stringifor

<span class="pl-k">implicit none</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string)              <span class="pl-k">::</span> csv            <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV file as a single stream.</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string), <span class="pl-k">allocatable</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> rows(:)        <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV table rows.</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string), <span class="pl-k">allocatable</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> columns(:)     <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV table columns.</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string), <span class="pl-k">allocatable</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> cells(:,:)     <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV table cells.</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(string)              <span class="pl-k">::</span> most_expensive <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The most expensive car.</span>
<span class="pl-k">real</span>(<span class="pl-c1">R8</span>P)                 <span class="pl-k">::</span> highest_cost   <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The highest cost.</span>
<span class="pl-k">integer</span>                   <span class="pl-k">::</span> rows_number    <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV file rows number.</span>
<span class="pl-k">integer</span>                   <span class="pl-k">::</span> columns_number <span class="pl-c">!&lt; The CSV file columns number.</span>
<span class="pl-k">integer</span>                   <span class="pl-k">::</span> r              <span class="pl-c">!&lt; Counter.</span>

<span class="pl-c">! parsing the just created CSV file: all done 9 statements!</span>
<span class="pl-k">call</span> csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>read_file(file<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>cars.csv<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)              <span class="pl-c">! read the CSV file as a single stream</span>
<span class="pl-k">call</span> csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>split(tokens<span class="pl-k">=</span>rows, sep<span class="pl-k">=</span>new_line(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>a<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>))   <span class="pl-c">! get the CSV file rows</span>
rows_number <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">size</span>(rows, dim<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>)                  <span class="pl-c">! get the CSV file rows number</span>
columns_number <span class="pl-k">=</span> rows(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>)<span class="pl-k">%</span><span class="pl-k">count</span>(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>,<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>) <span class="pl-k">+</span> <span class="pl-c1">1</span>          <span class="pl-c">! get the CSV file columns number</span>
<span class="pl-k">allocate</span>(cells(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>:columns_number, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>:rows_number)) <span class="pl-c">! allocate the CSV file cells</span>
<span class="pl-k">do</span> r<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>, rows_number                              <span class="pl-c">! parse all cells</span>
  <span class="pl-k">call</span> rows(r)<span class="pl-k">%</span>split(tokens<span class="pl-k">=</span>columns, sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>,<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)    <span class="pl-c">! get current columns</span>
  cells(<span class="pl-c1">1</span>:columns_number, r) <span class="pl-k">=</span> columns           <span class="pl-c">! save current columns into cells</span>
<span class="pl-k">enddo</span>

<span class="pl-c">! now you can do whatever with your parsed data</span>
<span class="pl-c">! print the table in markdown syntax</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>A markdown-formatted table<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(array<span class="pl-k">=</span>cells(:, <span class="pl-c1">1</span>), sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
columns <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>----<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! re-use columns for printing separators</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(array<span class="pl-k">=</span>columns, sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">do</span> r<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>, rows_number
  <span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(array<span class="pl-k">=</span>cells(:, r), sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>|<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">enddo</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span><span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-c">! find the most expensive car</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Searching for the most expensive car<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
most_expensive <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>unknown<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
highest_cost <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1._R8P</span>
<span class="pl-k">do</span> r<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">2</span>, rows_number
  <span class="pl-k">if</span> (cells(<span class="pl-c1">5</span>, r)<span class="pl-k">%</span>to_number(kind<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1._R8P</span>)&gt;<span class="pl-k">=</span>highest_cost) <span class="pl-k">then</span>
    highest_cost <span class="pl-k">=</span> cells(<span class="pl-c1">5</span>, r)<span class="pl-k">%</span>to_number(kind<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">1._R8P</span>)
    most_expensive <span class="pl-k">=</span> csv<span class="pl-k">%</span>join(array<span class="pl-k">=</span>[cells(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>, r), cells(<span class="pl-c1">3</span>, r)], sep<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span> <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>)
  <span class="pl-k">endif</span>
<span class="pl-k">enddo</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>The most expensive car is : <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span><span class="pl-k">//</span>most_expensive</pre></div>

<p>See the test program <a href="https://github.com/szaghi/StringiFor/blob/master/src/tests/csv_naive_parser.f90">csv_naive_parser</a> for a working example.</p>

<p>Obviously, this is a naive parser without any robustness, but it proves the usefulness of the StringiFor approach.</p>

<hr>

<h3><a id="user-content-methods-api" class="anchor" href="#methods-api" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Methods API</h3>

<p>In the following all the methods of <code>string</code> are listed with a brief description of their aim. The hyperlinks bring you to the full API explained into the GH pages.</p>

<h5><a id="user-content-builtins-replacements" class="anchor" href="#builtins-replacements" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>builtins replacements</h5>

<table><thead>
<tr>
<th>name</th>
<th>meaning</th>
</tr>
</thead><tbody>
<tr>
<td><a href="#adjustl">adjustl </a></td>
<td>adjustl replacement</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#adjustr">adjustr </a></td>
<td>adjustr replacement</td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td><a href="#count">count   </a></td>
<td>count replacement</td>
</tr>
<tr>

<td>index replacement</td>

<tr>
<td><a href="#len">len     </a></td>
<td>len replacement</td>
</tr>

<td><a href="#len_trim">len_trim</a></td>
<td>len_trim replacement</td>
</tr>

</tr>
</tbody></table>

<h2><a id="user-content-comparison-to-other-approaches" class="anchor" href="#comparison-to-other-approaches" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Comparison to other Approaches</h2>

<p>The lack of Fortran support for strings manipulation has promoted different solutions in the past years. Following the classification of Clive Page <a href="#clive-page-talk">[1]</a> we can consider:</p>

<ul>
<li>standard character type;</li>
<li>deferred-length allocatable character type (standard 2003+);</li>
<li><code>VARYING_STRING</code> type (standard 90/95+) as defined in ISO/IEC 1539-2:2000 (Varying length character strings).</li>
</ul>

<p>Let us compare StringiFor to the previous three approaches. In particular, let us consider Ian Harvey extension of <code>VARYING_STRING</code>, i.e. the <code>aniso_varying_string</code> <a href="#aniso_vstring">[2]</a>.</p>

<p>Clive Page had pointed out the following issues, among the others:</p>

<ul>
<li>fixed (at compile time) string length</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring <span class="pl-c">! further lengths different from 3 are not allowed</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>silent truncation on assignment</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">3</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>abcdefgh<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! silent trunctation at 'abc'</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>trim-cluttered code</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>abcdefgh<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
anotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">trim</span>(astring)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>ilmnopqrst<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! trim-cluttering is a necessity</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>handle significant trailing spaces</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Hello <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! for some reasons you want to keep these trailing white spaces</span>
anotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-k">trim</span>(astring)<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! you need trim because</span>
                                       <span class="pl-c">! len(astring)==len(anotherstring), but lost the significant</span>
                                       <span class="pl-c">! trailing spaces...</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>different character definition</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>         <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring<span class="pl-k">*</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>    <span class="pl-c">! old way</span>
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring <span class="pl-c">! new way</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>allocation of array of strings</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">10</span>), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring(:)
<span class="pl-k">allocate</span>(astring(<span class="pl-c1">100</span>)) <span class="pl-c">! all 100 elements of the array have 10 characters,</span>
                       <span class="pl-c">! different lengths cannot be declared</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>initialization of array of strings</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-c">! the following is illegal</span>
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">9</span>), <span class="pl-k">parameter</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> day(<span class="pl-c1">7</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> [<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Monday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,    &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Tuesday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,   &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Wednesday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Thursday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,  &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Friday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,    &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Saturday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>,  &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Sunday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>]
<span class="pl-c">! the following is legal, but cluttered by non significant trailing spaces</span>
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">9</span>), <span class="pl-k">parameter</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> day(<span class="pl-c1">7</span>) <span class="pl-k">=</span> [<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Monday   <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Tuesday  <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Wednesday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Thursday <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Friday   <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Saturday <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>, &amp;
                                         <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Sunday<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>]</pre></div>

<ul>
<li>IO limitations for non standard character variables</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>)             <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span>:), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(varying_string)          <span class="pl-k">::</span> yetanotherstring
<span class="pl-c">! fully-simple support for standard character variables</span>
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>abcdefgh<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span><span class="pl-k">*</span>, astring
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring
<span class="pl-k">read</span>(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>, <span class="pl-k">*</span>) astring
<span class="pl-c">! partial-simple support for standard deferred length-length allocatable character variables</span>
<span class="pl-c">! care must be placed in input operation...</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span><span class="pl-k">*</span>, anotherstring
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, anotherstring
<span class="pl-k">read</span>(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>, <span class="pl-k">*</span>) anotherstring
<span class="pl-c">! support depends on the implementation of the varying string type</span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span><span class="pl-k">*</span>, yetanotherstring
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(DT)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, yetanotherstring
<span class="pl-k">read</span>(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>, <span class="pl-k">*</span>) yetanotherstring</pre></div>

<ul>
<li>substring notation (slice)  for non standard character variables</li>
</ul>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>)             <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span>:), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring
<span class="pl-k">type</span>(varying_string)          <span class="pl-k">::</span> yetanotherstring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>abcdefgh<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
yetanotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> astring
anotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> astring(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>:<span class="pl-c1">6</span>)          <span class="pl-c">! allowed</span>
anotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> yetanotherstring(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>:<span class="pl-c1">6</span>) <span class="pl-c">! not allowed</span></pre></div>

<ul>
<li>passing string to procedures expecting standard character argument is <em>complicated</em></li>
</ul>

<p>Analyzing the above issues we can agree that deferred-length allocatable character and aniso_varyng_string approaches address many of them, at the cost of introducing some oddies.</p>

<h4><a id="user-content-deferred-length-allocatable-character" class="anchor" href="#deferred-length-allocatable-character" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>deferred-length allocatable character</h4>

<p>This approaches addresses all the issues related to the fixed length limitation, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span>:), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span>:), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> anotherstring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>Hello <span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
anotherstring <span class="pl-k">=</span> astring<span class="pl-k">//</span><span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>World<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span> <span class="pl-c">! trailing with spaces of astring correctly handled</span>
                                 <span class="pl-c">! no need of trim</span></pre></div>

<p>However, it has some limitations too. Aside the input operation, the most important (IMHO) are related to arrays of strings handling, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span>:), allocatable <span class="pl-k">::</span> asetofstring(:)
<span class="pl-k">allocate</span>(<span class="pl-k">character</span>(len<span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">99</span>) <span class="pl-k">::</span> asetofstring(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>)) <span class="pl-c">! all 10 elements must have len=99</span></pre></div>

<h4><a id="user-content-aniso_varying_string" class="anchor" href="#aniso_varying_string" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>aniso_varying_string</h4>

<p>Aniso_varying_string is an implemention of ISO/IEC 1539-2:2000 (Varying length character strings) developed by Ian Harvey that is internally based on a deferred-lenght allocatable character variable: it is essentially a derived type wrapping a deferred-lenght allocatable character. As a consequence, it has all the advantages of the deferred-length allocatable character approach. The wrapping approach addresses the arrays related issues, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">type</span>(varying_string), <span class="pl-k">allocatable</span> <span class="pl-k">::</span> asetofstring(:)
<span class="pl-k">allocate</span>(asetofstring(<span class="pl-c1">10</span>)) <span class="pl-c">! all 10 elements can have diffent lengths</span></pre></div>

<p>Its major issues are related to IO operations: however, this is addressed by new Fortran support for defined IO for derived type that make more effortless the IO of such an object. The other main issue is the impossibility to use the standard slice notation to access to substring: aniso_varying_string addresses (partially) this issue by public-exposing the wrapped allocatable character of its implementations thus allowing the slicing of it, e.g.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-source-fortran-modern"><pre><span class="pl-k">type</span>(varying_string) <span class="pl-k">::</span> astring
astring <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">'</span>abcdefg<span class="pl-pds">'</span></span>
<span class="pl-k">print</span> <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>(A)<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, astring<span class="pl-k">%</span>chars(<span class="pl-c1">2</span>:<span class="pl-c1">3</span>) <span class="pl-c">! print 'bc'</span></pre></div>

<h4><a id="user-content-stringifor" class="anchor" href="#stringifor" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>StringiFor</h4>

<p>StringiFor shares the same philosophy of aniso_varying_string, thut it has the same pros and cons. However, StringiFor is an Object Oriented Designed class, thus it has some peculiariaties distinguishing it from aniso_varying_string, see <a href="#stringifor-peculiarities">StringiFor Peculiarities</a>.</p>

<h4><a id="user-content-comparison-results" class="anchor" href="#comparison-results" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>Comparison results</h4>

<h5><a id="user-content-legend" class="anchor" href="#legend" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>legend</h5>

</tr>

<h3><a id="user-content-stringifor-peculiarities" class="anchor" href="#stringifor-peculiarities" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>StringiFor Peculiarities</h3>

<p>StringiFor publics an OOD class, the <code>string</code> object. This class is aimed to address all the issues of the standard character type, as ISO Varying String approaches do, but it is also designed to provide a features-rich string object as you can find on other languages like Python. As a matter of facts, the <em>auxiliary methods</em> added to the <code>string</code> object consitute a long list of new (for Fortraners) string-facilities, allowing you to handle strings effortless (cases-conversion, files-handling, encode/decode, numbers-casting, etc...), see the complete <a href="#methods-api">API</a>. It is worth to note that StringiFor is a tentative to adopt an fully OOD thus all methods and operators are TBP defined: to use StringiFor you can import only the <code>string</code> type, allowing a sane and robust names space handling. Only in the case you want the Fortran builtins to accept a <code>string</code> instead of a standard character type, e.g. to use <code>index(astring, 'c')</code> seamless with both a <code>type(string) :: astring</code> and a <code>character(99) :: astring</code>, you must use all the StringiFor public objects, including the overloaded interfaces of the Fortran builtins.</p>

<h4><a id="user-content-references" class="anchor" href="#references" aria-hidden="true"><svg aria-hidden="true" class="octicon octicon-link" height="16" version="1.1" viewBox="0 0 16 16" width="16"><path d="M4 9h1v1H4c-1.5 0-3-1.69-3-3.5S2.55 3 4 3h4c1.45 0 3 1.69 3 3.5 0 1.41-.91 2.72-2 3.25V8.59c.58-.45 1-1.27 1-2.09C10 5.22 8.98 4 8 4H4c-.98 0-2 1.22-2 2.5S3 9 4 9zm9-3h-1v1h1c1 0 2 1.22 2 2.5S13.98 12 13 12H9c-.98 0-2-1.22-2-2.5 0-.83.42-1.64 1-2.09V6.25c-1.09.53-2 1.84-2 3.25C6 11.31 7.55 13 9 13h4c1.45 0 3-1.69 3-3.5S14.5 6 13 6z"></path></svg></a>References</h4>

<p>[1]<a name="user-content-clive-page-talk"></a> <a href="http://www.fortran.bcs.org/2015/suggestion_string_handling.pdf"><em>Improved String-handling in Fortran</em></a>, Clive Page, October 2015.</p>

<p>[2]<a name="user-content-aniso_vstring"></a> <a href="http://www.megms.com.au/aniso_varying_string.htm"><em>aniso_varying_string</em></a>, Ian Harvey, 2016.</p>

<p>Go to <a href="#top">Top</a></p>
</article>
